sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÃ‰C unless otherwise noted.

div.head: Depositions on Defendant's part.
div.p:
Alice Humphry of Tickenham in the County of Somerset Spinster aged twenty years or thereabouts being sworne and examined on the Defendants part deposeth as followeth.
1.) To the first Interrogatory she saith that she knows the Complainant & the Defendant Thomas Edwards and hath known them for about four or five years past and alsoe knew Elianor Glanville deceased the Complainants mother in her lifetime and for about seaven years before her death which happened about two years since xxxxxxxxxxx
25.) To the twenty fifth Interrogatory she saith that before the death of the said Mrs Glanville she this Deponent was put by the parishoners of Tickenham to live with her as an apprentice and continued soe to live with her till the time of her death which was about seaven years and saith that during the time of this Deponents soe living with the xxxxxx
Mrs Glanville she the said Mrs Glanville did order & direct what was to be done in her Family and was during all that time in the Deponents Judgement very sensible of what she did and capable of ordering her servants and was not as every this Deponent knew of uncapable thereof by reason of any melancholly or madness

Mary Ashfeild spinster first sworne and examined on the Complainants part & againe sworne & examined on the part of the Defendant Deposeth as followeth.
29.) To the twenty nineth Interrogatory she saith that the Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick since the death of Mrs Glanville this Deponents late mother hath paid a debt which she the said Mrs Glanville owed to a Nurse for Nursing this Deponents sister Elianor Glanville which was about fourteen shillings due to xxxxx is the xxxxx
and hath also paid some finall debt for cheese to Tobias Hort But how much it was cannot set forth And Saith that she this Deponent Did about the Month of August last was twelve month receive from the said Defendant the summe of ten pounds as & for a legacy left her by her mothers Will and That she sab another xx
legatee in the said Will hath alsoe received of the said Defendant some money in part of his legacy given him therein but cannot set forth how much.
30.) To the thirtieth Interrogatory she saith that after the death of the said Mrs Glanville the said Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick Did give mourning to this Deponent of the vallue of about Seaven pounds and as this Defendant hath heard he alsoe gave this Deponents said sister Elianor Mourning and alsoe give give her pepihe
mothers Goldwatch & some part of her wearing apparel & all her household stuffe that was in her house at Tickenham & in Bristoll and this Deponent beleives that there yett remaines some part of her mothers household stuffe which was not delivered to this Deponent & her sister in the hands of Joseph Barnes
and Mary his wife and Elizabeth Knight of Tickenham.
31.) To the thirty first Interrogatory she saith that the said Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick from Michalmas last was twelve month which was some time after her mothers death hath allowed this Deponent a yearly sallary for her maintenance after the rate of thirty pounds by the year then afterward by quarter by
payment and she this Deponent hath received of him or his order two and twenty pounds and ten shillings for Nine months pay thereof due at Midsomer last and hath heard that the Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick hath allowed her said sister Elianor the same sallary Which allowance was xxxxxx
more than ever the said Mrs Glanville in her lifetime allowed or paid for this Deponent other said Sister and saith that she hath received more freindship and favours from the said Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick since her said mothers death than ever she received from her said mother in many years of her lifetime
32.) To the thirty second Interrogatory she saith That at the death of her said mother many of the houses & outhouses in Tickenham and Backwell being her said Mothers estate & the Walls & fences thereto belonging were very much out of repaire some of them being fallen down and others ready to fall
down And saith that the said Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick since her said mothers death hath repaired severall of the said houses outhouses Walls & fences in order to make them tenantable and hath expended & laid out a considerable summe of money thereabout but how much xxxxxxxxxxxxxx
34.) To the thirty fourth Interrogatory she saith that she was very well acquainted with the manner & caracter of handwriting of the said Elianor Glanville having often seen her write & verily beleives that the two letters now to her this Deponent produced the one of them dated at thely with whose words & signes
March the 13 1704 & signed on the other side with these words your humble servant E Glan And the other of them dated at the top with these words & figures Apr: the 14 1705 and ending at the bottom with these words Sir your humble servant E Glanvile and both directed to the Defendant Edwards xxxxxx
proper handwriting of this Deponents said mother.

Arthur Hoskins of Clapton in the County of Somerset husbandman aged forty five years or thereabouts being sworne and examined deposeth as followeth.
1.) To the first Interrogatory he saith that he knows the Complainant & hath known him for about ten years past and alsoe knew Elianor Glanville deceiced the plaintiffs mother in her life time and for about ten years before her death which happened about two years since
23.) To the twenty third Interrogatory he saith that in the life time of the said Mrs Glanville & as near as he can remember twas about a year and halfe before her death she employed & directed this Deponent as her servant or agent to goe into Wales and buy some cattle for her for which purpose she gave this Deponent money and directed him to buy
small Cattle for that they were fittest for her purpose being to be kept in her woods And further saith that he accordingly went into Wales to buy such Cattle but not finding such Cattle there as he was directed to buy he this Deponent bought the smallest he could but could not get them soe small as the said Mrs Glanville desired
and saith he brought the Cattle soe by him 4 bought to Tickenham & delivered them to the said Mrs Glanville or her servants for which Journey and business the said Mrs Glanville paid & satisfyed this Deponent to content and Saith he was soe employed by the said Mrs Glanville as he beleives through the recommendation of a neighbour
of his one Bryant who represented this Deponent to the said Mrs Glanville as a fit person for such business being used to it and saith that the direccions he recieved from the said Mrs Glanville thereabouts were given sensibly in this Deponents Judgement & in manner as other persons used to give.

Elizabeth Whitfeild of the parish of Tickenham in the County of Somersett spinster aged six & twenty years or thereabouts being Sworne & examined deposeth as followeth.
1.) To the first Interrogatory she saith that she knows the Complainant & hath known him for severall years past and hath seen the Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick once but is not acquainted with him but very well knew Elianor Glanville the plaintiffs late mother deceased for about fourteen or fifteen years in her life time & that xxxx
22.) To the twenty second Interrogatory she saith that in the wime of this Deponents knowledge of the said Mrs Glanville as aforesaid she this Deponent had for about three years of that time reckonings & accounts with her relating to the rent of an estate of hers which this Deponents father in law William Fuller xxxxx deceased
did rent of the said Mrs Glanville Which accounts this Deponent on behalfe of her said father in law did severall times in that time passe & settle with the said Mrs Glanville. In passing and settling whereof she this Deponent did observe and take the said Mrs Glanville to be a woman
of good sense and understanding and did act sensible as one that understood the business she was about and was not in this Deponents Judgement delirious frenzy or void of understanding but would sometimes be in a passion & very Trasty as another body may be but it was soon over with her
and saith that the indented paper or account now by this Deponent produced signed E Glanvile and purporting to be an agreement between the said William Fuller & the said Mrs Glanville dated April 20 1708 is the same accompt Which the said Mrs Glanville gave this Deponent on her said father in lawe
account at the last time of this Deponent soe settling accounts with her & very well remembers that the said Mrs Glanville Did indent the said paper or account now produced with another part thereof which she kept herselfe.

Hester Hort wife of John Hort of Tickenham in the County of Somersett husbandman aged thirty years or thereabouts being sworne & examined deposeth as followeth.
1.) To the first Interrogatory she saith she knows the Complainant & hath known him from her infancy being borne and bred near one another in the same parish alsoe knew Elianor Glanville the Complainants late mother deceased in her life time and for as long time as this Deponent can remember and that she dyed near about two years since.
10.) To the tenth Interrogatory she saith that she was very well acquainted with the said Mrs Glanville for many years in her lifetime & was very often conversant with her and saith that in such her conversacion with the said Mrs Glanville they had some times discourse touching or relating to the plaintiff
as to his behaviour & way of living and this Deponent very well remembers that about three years since being in Company with the said Mrs Glanville at Tickenham Court where she then lived and discoursing with her concerning her sone the plaintiff the said Mrs Glanville told this Deponent that her said son should be noe more the better
for her estate than this Deponent should be upon which this Deponent said to her why Madam you won't disinherite him or to that effect she replyed to this Deponent that she was sure if he had it he would passe it away or to that effect and saith that the said Mrs Glanville hath often complained to this Deponent of the
undutifullnesse of the plaintiff and other her children towards her and of the plaintiff extravagency in keeping bad company and spending of money & seemed to be very much concerned thereat and would often say to this Deponent that if they would reclaime she would take them into her favour and the Deponent
saith that she hath often seen the Complainant and his brother and sisters in the company of their said mother and did not observe any undutifullness then towards her but they seemed very quiet & easy with her.

John Fuller of Tickenham in the County of Somersett yeoman aged three and thirty years or thereabouts being sworne & examined deposeth as followeth.
1.) To the first Interrogatory he saith that he knows the Complainant and hath known him for severall years past and also knows the Defendant Sir Henry Goodrick and hath known him for about a twelve month past and very well knew Elianor Glanville the plaintiffs late mother deceased in her life time
& for about fifteen years before her death which happened about a year and an halfe since.
12.) To the twelfth Interrogatory he saith that he hath heard that the plaintiff in his mothers life time did lay some claime to her estate and that he subpenad her in Chancery thereabout But doth not know that the plaintiff did then threaten to take away the tennants corne thereon But this
Deponent being about seven or eight years since a tennant for part of the said Mrs Glanville's estate at Tickenham and by the high winds some of the trees being blown down some she the said Mrs Glanville did give this Deponent three or four Elme trees and the Complainant understanding
thereof did forbid this Deponent to take to the same trees threatening this Deponent that if he did he should pay for it whereupon this Deponent did not take to the same till after Mrs Glanville came back from London and when the law suite was over between the plaintiff and his said Mother as
this Deponent understood.
22.) To the twenty second Interrogatory he saith that for severall years before the death of the said Mrs Glanville he this Deponent did rent some part of her estate at Tickenham Sometimes a small part thereof & other times a greater part thereof & perticularly about two years before her death he rented forty pounds a year of
her and was in the possession of that part at her death & did sometimes buy hay of her & by meanes thereof he this Deponent became very well acquainted with her and had severall reckonings and accounts with her touching the rents of the said estate & the Hay by him soe bought
& saith that during all the time which this Deponent soe rented her estate and had such dealings with her she was as this Deponent observed & always found her a woman of good sense and understanding and was not as ever he observed any ways void of understanding & saith that in all
the convernes which this Deponent had with her in letting her estates & passing her accounts she did act sensible and as one that understood the business she was about & seemed to act very close for her own interest.
32.) To the two and thirtieth Interrogatory he saith that the greatest part of the houses & outhouses in Tickenham & at Backwell being the said Mrs Glanvilles estate at the time of her death were very much out of repaire as was also the Walls and fences thereto belonging
some of them being fallen downe & others ready to fall downe and saith that the deponent Sir Henry Goodrick has since her death repaired severall of the said houses outhouses Walls & fences in order to make them tenantable And doth not know that anything has been
laid out thereon other than what was necessary but all of them are not yett repaire.

xxx thrupp
Thomas Waller
Thomas Oldfeild
Samuel Fox
